importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The subprime car delinquency rate doubled from 2021, marking a significant economic shift and a key point in tracking economic deterioration.
The default rate among subprime borrowers reached nearly 10% in September, indicating high levels of financial distress and vehicle repossession risks.
Motor vehicle repair costs surged 15% year-over-year in August, highlighting rising ownership costs and financial strain on consumers.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2021 to 2025 shows a doubling of subprime car loan delinquency, illustrating a worsening economic condition and a growing crisis in consumer credit.

keyTakeAways: The delinquency rate for subprime car borrowers (credit score below 670) has doubled since 2021, reaching 6.43%, which is higher than during any of the past three recessions.
This rate is the second-highest since the early 1990s, with the only higher level occurring in January of this year.
Car repossession rates have reached their highest level since the Great Recession of 2008–2009.
A growing number of subprime borrowers have no room for error due to high monthly payments, rising repair and insurance costs, and pre-existing financial burdens.
Half of new and 46% of used car loans have payments of $500 or more; 8% of new loans exceed $1,000 monthly.
Motor vehicle repair costs increased 15% year-over-year in August, the largest annual surge in nearly two years.
Car insurance rates rose by nearly 5% in August, a significant jump above inflation.
The financial strain is compounded by years of inflation, the resumption of student loan payments, and credit score changes affecting borrowing costs.
Prime borrowers (higher credit scores) show minimal delinquency (under 0.5%), highlighting a 'K-shaped economy' where wealthier consumers fare better than lower-income ones.
Lenders are implementing GPS tracking and ignition disabling in vehicles to facilitate repossession, indicating a high volume of defaults.

namedEntities.name: Fitch Ratings
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Fitch Ratings provides the data showing the doubling of subprime car loan delinquency since 2021, which is a key metric in assessing economic health.

namedEntities.name: Cox Automotive
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A financial data and automotive analytics company
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Cox Automotive reports on the default rate among subprime borrowers, showing a nearly 10% default rate in September, which signals serious financial distress.

namedEntities.name: Experian
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Experian provides data on car loan payment levels, showing a significant portion of new and used car loans have payments of $500 or more.

namedEntities.name: Bureau of Labor Statistics
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal agency that collects economic data
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Bureau of Labor Statistics reports a 15% year-over-year surge in repair costs, indicating rising costs of car ownership and financial stress.

namedEntities.name: Jonathan Smoke
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Jonathan Smoke highlights the lack of room for error among subprime borrowers, emphasizing the severity of financial stress in the auto loan sector.

namedEntities.name: Rod Chadehumbe
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chief asset-backed securities strategist at Bloomberg Intelligence
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rod Chadehumbe notes that prime borrowers are not struggling, underscoring the K-shaped economy where only lower-income groups face financial hardship.

namedEntities.name: Pamela Foohey
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Law professor at University of Georgia and expert in auto finance and bankruptcies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pamela Foohey explains how lenders are using GPS tracking and ignition disabling to recover reposessed vehicles, indicating high default volumes.

namedEntities.name: George Badeen
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: President of Midwest Recovery and Adjustment in Detroit and a trade group leader
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: George Badeen compares current repo volumes to those during the Great Recession, suggesting the current economic situation is as severe as past downturns.

namedEntities.name: Subprime borrowers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This group faces the highest delinquency and repossession rates, signaling systemic financial instability among lower-income Americans.

namedEntities.name: Prime borrowers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Prime borrowers show very low delinquency, highlighting the unequal impact of economic stress and the 'K-shaped economy' phenomenon.

namedEntities.name: Car loans
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Car loans are central to the article as a barometer of consumer financial health and stability, especially for low-income borrowers.

namedEntities.name: Auto payments
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rising auto payments are a primary driver of financial distress, especially when combined with inflation and stagnant wages.

namedEntities.name: Student loans
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The resumption of student loan payments after pandemic pauses has increased financial pressure on borrowers, worsening car loan default rates.

namedEntities.name: Great Recession (2008–2009)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Current car loan delinquency and repossession levels are being compared to the Great Recession, signaling a potential return to crisis-level economic conditions.

namedEntities.name: K-shaped economy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Economic phenomenon where different groups experience divergent outcomes
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article uses the K-shaped economy to explain how wealthier Americans are doing well while lower-income borrowers face severe financial hardship.

namedEntities.name: Repossession
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Legal process to recover a vehicle due to unpaid loans
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Repossession rates are at their highest since 2008, indicating a major downturn in consumer financial health and rising economic risk.

namedEntities.name: Credit score
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Credit scores are used as a key filter for borrower groups (subprime vs. prime), showing how financial risk varies by income and credit history.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A significant increase in car loan delinquency among Americans with credit scores below 670—up to 6.43% since 2021—has raised alarms among economists, marking the second-highest level since the early 1990s. This trend, which surpasses delinquency rates during past recessions, reflects deepening financial stress caused by record auto payments, soaring repair and insurance costs, and the resumption of student loan payments. Despite a slight stabilization in 2025, economists warn that a weakening labor market and increasing layoffs could worsen the crisis. Unlike prime borrowers, who show minimal delinquency, subprime borrowers face overwhelming financial pressure, often unable to sell their vehicles due to negative equity. The situation exemplifies a 'K-shaped economy' where wealthier consumers thrive while lower-income Americans struggle. Lenders are actively using GPS tracking and ignition disabling to recover vehicles, signaling that current delinquency and repossession levels are nearing or matching those seen during the Great Recession.
title: A significant group of Americans are falling behind on their car payments - an economic warning sign
